clinicalDescription: Overview: A circulatory condition in which narrowed blood vessels reduce blood flow to the limbs (can be due to arteriosclerosis). PVD is known as: arteriosclerosis obliterans, arterial insufficiency of the legs, claudication, and intermittent claudication. Two main types of PVD are functional and organic PVD. Presentation: Pain, fatigue often in legs and during exercise, reduced hair growth on legs, skin color changes (reddish blue or pale), weak pulses (in legs and feet), wounds or ulcers that will not heal. Assessment: Measuring the pulses in legs and feet, doppler untrasound, ankle-brachial index (ABI), angiography, magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), computerized tomography angiography (CTA) Plan: Lifestyle changes - tobacco cessation, exercise, and a healthy diet. Medications (cilostazol or pentoxifylline, clopidogrel, aspirin, statins, ACE inhibitors), angioplasty or vascular surgery. Prognosis: No cure. PVD responds to lifestyle treatments and medications as needed.
